author: zsfelfoldi
content:
I checked the latest EIP updates and now there is a different `Selfdestruct(address,uint256)` event ID defined just for selfdestructs that burn the ETH (send to same address). At the same time, selfdestructs transferring to a different address are still logged as standard ERC-20 `Transfer(address,address,uint256)`. Does this make sense? It just doesn't look elegant. It does not distinguish the selfdestruct-originated events, yet it uses a separate `Selfdesctuct` for some selfdestructs.
The real distinction here is that the amount is burned, and maybe we'll also want to log other burned amounts in the future. I'd suggest to call it `Burn(address,uint256)` instead.

Disregard this.  the balance burn happens immediately in the case where a contract created in the current transaction selfdestructs to self

author: jwasinger
content: But... if an account selfdestructs to self, and ether is sent to it later on in the same transaction, the new balance will be burned when the account is removed at tx finalization.

author: jwasinger
content: so we do need to specify what to do in this weird edge-case, and I have adjusted the PR to specify this
